awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Studies of Heavy Quarkonium Production in Relativistic Heavy-Ion Collisions at UC Davis.
awd_abstract_narration:
CAREER: Studies of Heavy Quarkonium Production in Relativistic Heavy-Ion Collisions at UC Davis.
Abstract:
In the study of the basic interactions of nature, one of the most intriguing is the strong nuclear interaction.  This is the force which deals with quarks and gluons, which are the elementary particles that make up protons and neutrons, and are therefore the basic building blocks of all the matter we see around us. A key property of the strong interaction is that quarks and gluons are never seen in isolation, a phenomenon called "confinement". This behavior changes when nuclear matter is heated to extreme conditions.  Calculations predict that normal nuclear matter exists up to a certain temperature. Above this temperature, there is a cross-over to a phase where nucleons dissolve such that their inner quarks and gluons are liberated.  These "deconfined" quarks and gluons thus form a new state of nuclear matter, which has been called the Quark-Gluon Plasma (QGP).  A few microseconds after the Big Bang, the universe is believed to have crossed this phase boundary, condensing from a QGP to a hadron gas as the temperature decreased.  In the experimental front, producing the QGP in the laboratory and studying its properties is the main goal of experiments with heavy-ion collisions at high-energies.  Two key issues in this search are a) producing evidence that the matter produced in the collisions consists of deconfined quarks and gluons, and b) determining that the temperature of the produced system is above the cross-over temperature.  There are several avenues to attack the above issues, and in this proposal, one of them is addressed. This is the study of particles made of relatively heavy quark-antiquark pairs, which are bound by the strong force. These states are interesting because in a QGP, the high temperatures and the presence of deconfined lighter quarks and gluons modify the spectral properties of these heavy quark-antiquark states such that they no longer bind. When a heavy-ion collision forms a QGP, the production of these states is therefore suppressed relative to proton+proton or deuteron+nucleus collisions where no QGP is formed, providing a signature for deconfinement.  Since the ground states and the excited states of these quark-antiquark particles melt at different temperatures, measuring the relative ratios provides experimentalists with a thermometer for this extremely hot matter.  In this proposal, the Principal Investigator will measure the production of the heaviest available quark-antiquark bound states in heavy ion collisions.  The investigations will be carried out at the highest energy accelerators for heavy ion collisions: with the STAR detector at the Relativistic Heavy-Ion Collider located in Brookhaven National Laboratory (Long Island, NY) and with the CMS detector at the Large Hadron Collider in the European Laboratory for High Energy Physics (CERN, Geneva, Switzerland).
The PI will maintain an outreach program focusing on three components.  He will mentor undergraduate students participating in the REU program at Davis.  He is a member of the Society of the Advancement of Chicanos and Native Americans in Science (SACNAS). Through SACNAS, the PI communicates the excitement of heavy-ion research to future Latino scientists, mentors students during their annual conference, participates in the selection of student posters, and judges student presentations.  Finally, he will develop physics presentations and demonstrations for the science students of the Cesar Chavez School, a Spanish-immersion school in Davis.

por.por_cntn:
This project involved the study of QCD (Quantum Chromo-Dynamics), the theory of the strong interactions, which fundamentally is at the heart of particles such as protons and neutrons. This is a theory whose main actors are quarks and gluons, which are the particles which help make protons and neutrons.  One of the features of our world is that we do not see quarks and gluons as isolated particles. The nature of the strong interaction prevents quarks and gluons from appearing by themselves.  The study of relativistic heavy ion collisions has as its aim the observation and characterization of a state of matter in which quarks and gluons can act over a volume larger than that of a proton, and move relatively unimpeded within this volume.  This state of matter is called the Quark Gluon Plasma, and has been the subject of many years of study.   In this project, the first measurments of particles made of bottom quarks in heavy ion collisions were carried out. We measured their rate of production and have observed that these particles have a much more difficult time forming than in nucleon-nucleon collisions: we see much less of these particles than would be expected if a heavy ion collision was a superposition of individual nucleon-nucleon collisions. Such an effect was predicted if a Quark Gluon Plasma is formed in the collision due to the presence of the additional quarks and gluons and the QCD interaction between these and the bottom quarks.  Not only do the particles made of bottom quarks signal the presence of the Quark Gluon Plasma, but they can also help to characterize its temperature.  In additon, by studying one of the carriers of the electro-weak force, the Z0 boson, we have established that its rate of production is not modified.  This is expected for a particle that does not interact via QCD, such as the Z0, and in particular when it decays into particles such as muons or electrons which also do not interact via QCD.  This result confirms that for such particles, the rate of production in Pb+Pb is consistent with being a simple superposition of nucleon-nucleon collisions. The Z0 can serve as a standard candle of the initial state in PbPb collisions. These studies represent a significant step in our exploration of QCD, which is one of the least understood of the fundamental forces of nature.

 

In addition to the research pursued, the project included a significant component of training of graduate students and undergraduate students. Two doctoral theses were finished in this project, and 4 more were started and are ongoing.

A very important component of the project involved reaching out to students from underrepresented minorities, in particular among the Latino community.  This was accomplished through mentoring of students in the SACNAS conference and in the UC Davis SACNAS chapter, through visits to elementary schools, and through contact with high-school students via visits to the UC Davis campus and also online via the "Adopt-A-Physicist" program.  These activities help inspire the next generation of leaders in science and technology.
